When an incident occurs (particularly an incident that causes
loss or injury), someone needs to investigate the reasons for the occurrence
be called upon to perform the investigation?

The short answer is anyone in the workplace may be called upon at any time to complete an investigation. However, the persons investigating should understand the principles of an investigation and understand why the investigation is taking place. Generally, the people involved are
(those with an interest in the investigation).
or individual affected by an issue
investigation process or company interests in the investigation
interested party that affects the development, performance
and effect of safety within an organization
internal or external stakeholders with an interest in the investigation

Stakeholders can be from various roles, positions, and backgrounds. In fact, some individuals identified as a stakeholder for one investigation may not be a stakeholder for another.
will always be involved in every investigation. Some stakeholders
and safety representatives or Joint Health and Safety Committee members
particularly with major incidents or incidents with
Note that this is not a comprehensive list and other people may be identified as stakeholders.
(Only used if VO doesn’t match onscreen text)
Some of the best investigators work in teams to complete effective, detailed, and solutions-based investigations. The reasons for investigating with a team include the following:
Teams with members from different backgrounds (i.e. someone with an engineering, medical, or other viewpoint

) assist investigators in developing different perspectives on the incident and allows a more complete picture to emerge. Each team should ideally have at least two or three people with various specialties (ranging from engineers to safety professionals, to medical specialists
even for an incident that appears to be simple, may turn out to have many complex factors involved
complete a more thorough investigation. An investigation team also helps to
speed up an incident investigation process while improving the outcome of the process

When major events occur (such as a plane crash, chemical explosion, train derailment, etc.), large-scale investigations are required. In some particularly large-scale incidents, multiple investigations with multiple investigators are necessary to uncover the factors leading up to the incident. This is especially important to resolve the investigation in a timely manner. Some examples of major events include

Stakeholders can come from internal and external sources. They are differentiated as follows:
This includes many individuals in the workplace and may include:
Worker representatives (union if unionized or employee association)
Preventive maintenance and/or set up staff
This includes many individuals external to the workplace and may include:
Emergency services: fire, paramedic, police, etc.

Role of Health and Safety Members
Investigation teams will sometimes include Joint Health and Safety Committee members.
Well-trained Joint Health and Safety Committee members actively involved in all incident investigations, no matter what the size,
including them in the team include:
Legislation and regulations vary by jurisdiction
and Joint Health and Safety Committee members would possess knowledge of the particulars
provide firsthand knowledge of the people, machinery, tools
and equipment that even a good supervisor may miss during an investigation
are aware of issues that are important to the investigation
ring credibility to the investigation as a solution
based rather than fault-based investigation process
can rapidly evaluate and control an incident to everyone’s satisfaction
members will assist significantly, despite occasional differences of opinion.

(Only used if VO doesn’t match onscreen text)
When an event occurs that requires investigation, the supervisor is an important contributor and point of contact. The supervisor’s importance stems from the following three factors:
The supervisor is or should be, readily available, allowing them to start an investigation right away. While other staff may investigate incidents that occur
‘office hours’ easily, many incidents occur on off-shifts and weekends when other staff are not available.
to show leadership in their organization. The role of supervisors varies from organization to organization and this
the incident investigation process. In some
supervisors are more like ‘lead hands’ and their function is mainly
ensuring that staffing is available, dealing with minor problems, etc.
While safety legislation may describe who is a supervisor in one way
an organization may describe the supervisor in another way.
In most jurisdictions, management is accountable for safety. This extends to incident investigation. Most organizations expect their supervisors to conduct a minimal investigation including basic

items below to learn more. Then, click the ‘Next’ arrow to continue.

do not often perform investigations. In many workplaces, such as an office environment, supervisors may not see an incident for long periods. They may have trouble, even with regular training, to complete the basic required forms, let alone conduct a thorough investigation.
Supervisors may not have the right skill sets.
If a company is small with a few employees an incident could occur every 5-7 years, so incident investigations are not a daily or annual activity.
need another person/resource in the organization or an external investigator to assist them in order for them to conduct an investigation
Joint Health and Safety Committee member
may support and act as an advisor
investigator is often a difficult balancing act.
Some incident investigations, especially those involving technical areas,
may want to turn control over to another team, department, safety coordinator or human resources member while staying in contact with
own workplace and staff presents a conflict or bias to the investigation process. Supervisors are responsible

the company and have specific responsibilities under legislation and regulations. When a supervisor is responsible for the safety of their employees, it is difficult to be objective if the supervisor failed to meet his or her responsibilities.

Involving stakeholders at any level of an investigation is going to require management of the stakeholders and the process.
The size and complexity of the organization will determine the number of stakeholders.
Effective incident investigations begin even before an incident
stakeholder relationships is fundamental in that it builds a relationship of trust that is open, honest, and straightforward in dealing with stakeholders.
While planning and developing your investigation program,
should include a stakeholder list along with contact information and areas of responsibility.
The lack of stakeholder identification usually results in individuals, areas, or senior managers not being included in the investigation process.

This is also an opportune time to identify members of any investigation teams. Adapted from the CSA Z1005 Standard, an investigation team is, “the person or people assigned by an organization to perform investigations as outlined in the company investigation procedure, policy or program.”
An effective way to engage individuals within an organization in the incident investigation process is to establish an

Which of the following people are potential stakeholders in an investigation? Select all that apply.
Since employees have direct experience in both the industry and their organization, they are the most important factor in creating and supporting a safety system

Supervisors (or persons in a supervisory role) must initiate all investigations. If the supervisor finds that he or she does not possess the required technical knowledge, additional resources may be used, but the supervisor remains in charge of the investigation.
Which of the following statements are true? Select all that apply.
When planning your investigation program, you should create a stakeholder list including contact information and areas of responsibility.
The size and complexity of the organization determines the number of stakeholders.
A supervisor investigating his or her own workplace presents a bias to the investigation process.
Supervisors are important to investigations because they possess intimate knowledge of safety legislation.
Managing stakeholder relationships is fundamental. These relationships should be open, honest, and straightforward and should be established before an incident even occurs.

The organization needs to identify the roles and responsibilities of individuals during an investigation.
Processes should be in place to
review and maintain the procedure to ensure that the roles and responsibilities are updated and changed as the organization grows or changes

According to the CSA Z1005 Standard,
is defined as, “the demonstrated ability to apply OHS knowledge and skills to the incident investigation process.”

Investigators and investigation team members should possess very specific competencies including skills such as hazard identification, risk assessment, and risk control principles used during investigations. To ensure that investigators are competent, the organization needs to identify the roles and responsibilities of the investigation team, identify the required skills, and recognize the need for ongoing skill development and maintenance.
An incident requiring an investigation can be traumatic for the workplace and the employees. An approach is required to ensure that future investigators develop their skills
need mentors to assist in completing an investigation.
The level and type of mentorship may vary
training and skill development for incident investigation is critical. In particular, supervisors are critical to the investigation process, since they understand the process, operations, workers
Some workplaces select individuals with none of the appropriate skills or knowledge to investigate, and therefore are not successful in the

possess certain skills and abilities. They should

Individual investigators on the team should be able to:
Identify different hazards such as chemical, biological, environmental, mechanical, musculoskeletal, psychosocial, etc. (More information on types of hazards are described in
independently and in a team environment
and manage priorities to ensure tasks are completed in a timely manner
, compile, safeguard, catalogue, assess, analyze, verify, and record relevant data based on observation, scene review, interviews, inquiries, record review, documentation, and inspections
Individual investigators on the team require specific communication skills. They should be able to:
prepare written materials such as incident reports, emails, presentations, etc.
critique procedures for accuracy, clarity, and consistency with organizational policies and
convey findings at a level appropriate to the various audiences involved
listen to information and concerns and to clarify and validate received messages
with other parties, agencies, or outside authorities, as applicable
Individual investigators on the team require specific leadership, management, and guidance skills. They should be able to:
leadership, including the ability to thoroughly take control of a situation
with potentially upset, difficult, or uncooperative people
verbal communication skills, including the ability to convey information both from and to groups and individuals
and preserve a scene to conserve data and ensure the safety of others
and ensure that the investigation remains objective.
